name: Wouter Kreuze
summary:
Since my positions at the university and the embassy, I have been applying the extensive knowledge obtained across a broad range of academic disciplines in the working environment. In these activities, I have been responsible for the transcribing and interpreting of primary sources in order to assure their correct entry into the database as well as the writing and editing of texts with different purposes.

During my time as a student I combined two academic disciplines in the form of a double bachelor – History and Italian – supported by many extracurricular courses from other disciplines, such as philosophy and history of art. During the almost two years that I resided in Italy for education and an internship, I have been able to deepen my knowledge of the culture and language of the peninsula. Nowadays, I aim to improve my vocabulary of the Italian language in less colloquial areas, such as academic and literary jargon.

My internship at the Royal Dutch Embassy in Rome took place at a very important moment, namely the state visit of the Royal Couple to Italy. Therefore, during my work there, this was one of my most important activities. Next to this, I also conducted a research during these six months, aiming to find simple means of measuring the effect of the embassy’s cultural policy. Then, there were also a range of smaller activities I took care of, such as regularly updating the social media of the embassy as well as the publishing of newsletters.

In the three years that I worked as a student-assistant in a digitalization project, I was responsible for the entry of the documents in the database, from transcribing and correcting earlier transcriptions to the entry of the basic features and the writing of summaries.

In my free time I enjoy to read and collect literature, with special attention to the classics of (Italian) history. This includes both prose and verse, fiction such as novels, but also works on history and philosophy.

name: Muhammad Deen
summary: Current Master's student at the University of Amsterdam (UvA) in English Literature and Culture. I am also an experienced Program Assistant with a long history of working in museums and cultural institutions in New York City. Bachelor's Degree in History and English Literature from Baruch College, City University of New York (CUNY).

name: Juliet van den Nieuwendijk
summary:
From 2013 to 2019, I have studied the BSc Criminology and the BA International Bachelor History at the Erasmus University Rotterdam (Netherlands). I was able to go on an exchange twice to the University of Glasgow (Scotland) where I followed classes from the sociology and the politics department. 

In 2019 I worked for six months as an intern for the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Department of Stability and Humanitarian Aid (Stability and Security Division). At the same time I wrote my bachelor thesis on Dutch Women in Peacekeeping Operations and UNSCR1325.

After I graduated and finished my internship, I decided to take a gap year and travelled from the Netherlands to Russia and from there overland to Australia. When I returned to the Netherlands I worked for the Dutch Ministry of Justice and Security, for the Immigration and Naturalisation Service.

I've started my MA International Law and Human Rights at the UN Mandated University for Peace in October 2020 and graduated in December 2021. For the last six months I worked as an intern for the United Nations, Department of Peacekeeping Operations (Gender Unit) in New York City, USA.

Recently I've returned to the Netherlands and started working for the Ministry of Justice and Security. 

https://julietvdn.weebly.com/

name: Vincent Veerbeek
degree 2: Research Master Historical, Literary and Cultural Studies
skills: ['Academisch schrijven', 'Academische publicaties', 'Tekstredactie', 'Datamanagement', 'Microsoft Excel', 'Online journalistiek', 'Fotografie', 'Foreign Languages', 'Redactiewerk', 'Writing', 'Newsletters', 'Creative Writing', 'Research', 'Bloggen', 'Wetenschappelijk schrijven', 'Vertalen', 'Journalistiek', 'Sociale media', 'Microsoft Word', 'MailChimp']
summary:
I am an internationally oriented storyteller with ambitions to develop myself further as a researcher, a journalist, and an author. Through a combination of creativity and analysis, I continuously try to improve my understanding of the world and bring others along on that journey. At the moment, I am putting my passions for research and writing to use as a doctoral student at the University of Helsinki. My dissertation project concerns the role of music in United States boarding schools for Native American children in the 19th and 20th centuries.

During my time as a student of American Studies and History at Radboud University in Nijmegen, I became acquainted with the different ways of conveying a story, from academic publications and journalistic articles to literature and photography. I switch effortlessly between Dutch and English, and time spent living in the United States has made me culturally versatile as well. In addition, my role as a member of various (editorial) boards and committees has taught me to work in a team, exercise leadership, and above all to be open to new challenges.

name: Gijs Weijkamp
skills: ['Google Ads', 'Betaalde social media marketing', 'Content-strategie', 'Webcontent schrijven', 'CRM', 'Planning marketingevenementen', 'Klantenondersteuning']
summary:
Student Communication Science with a Political Science background. In 2017 I started the Bachelor's programme Political Science at Radboud University. I'm interested in recent political-societal issues and international relations. I've lived in the United States (Memphis, TN) for six months to study American politics and Strategic Media in an international environment.

After receiving my Bachelor's degree, I changed course and started with the Communication Science program. Since 2018, I work at the Marketing & Communications department of Radboud University. I started as study advisor for prospective students and I'm now coordinating the Bachelor's Open Days. I also assist our CRM team with their projects. My work inspired me to dive deeper into the communications field, specifically into marketing communication, social media, and content marketing.

Born and raised in the 'Achterhoek' (Eastern part of The Netherlands) but since 2017 I've found my place in the city of Nijmegen. I like to take on new challenges, present my ideas, and critically review the cases I come across.

summary:
I am an experienced professional who enjoys driving the development of others. I am a natural people person, highly organized, and able to manage a varied workload with a creative and positive can-do approach.

Living and working abroad leads to personal and often professional growth and my international experience have added a range of new soft and interpersonal skills to my skill set.

I firmly believe in the value of sharing, collaboration, and innovation to achieve results. That's why I am open to working with companies that have ambitions, challenges, and goals.

name: Theresa Rauch
summary:
In 2022, I completed by BA in History with Honours and cum laude distinction at Utrecht University (Netherlands). I am now pursuing an International Joint MA in Peace and Conflict Studies at the University of Kent (United Kingdom) and the Philipps-Universität Marburg (Germany). 

My academic fields of interest are post-conflict societies, transitional justice, and gendered experiences of peace, conflict and displacement. I wrote my Bachelor thesis on the accessibility of reparations for survivors of conflict-related sexual violence in post-war Bosnia and Herzegovina.

Beyond this, I am passionate about issues of gender and inequality, intersectionality, and decolonisation.

name: Devin Vartija
summary:
I am currently assistant professor in political history at Utrecht University, where I received my Ph.D. with a cum laude distinction in May, 2018. I am also a postdoctoral fellow at the Ecole des hautes études en sciences sociales. My first book, The Color of Equality: Race and Common Humanity in Enlightenment Thought, will be published by University of Pennsylvania Press in June 2021. It systematically interrogates the strands of equality and inequality, common humanity and racial classification, that run through Enlightenment thought, attempting to address the contradictory legacies wrought by the Enlightenment.

For me, history springs from the perennial human concern with self-discovery. While historical research and writing can never be completely shorn of its political nature, I believe that this work can also be considered an anthropological science which adds many layers of understanding to present-day problems. Scholarship in history can thus demonstrate the numerous ways in which our contemporary moment is a contingent one where our individual and collective choices matter.
